instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: Hi all, have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> on my bench that won't turn on, has no green light and pulls 42mA from the power supply. I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> as 0.6v and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> as 0.1v, but I'm not sure what to investigate from here. No super obvious spots of corrosion or gunk anywhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
I suppose a leakage problem.
Post <SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
Did you try with lab PSU, or fake charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 18.5v, this is with a lab PSU and genuine Magsafe

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at L7095 and L7130.
Also check <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>.
Post <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
Diode mode at L7130 is 0.159 on either side, but at L7095 it's 0.001 on either side, so this means something is shorting this to ground right?
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
Pin 1 - 0.58v
Pin 2 - 0.18v
Pin 3 - 1.18v
Pin 4 - 0.32v
Pin 6 - 17.74v
Pin 8 - 17.74v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
You can use voltage injection method in this case.
Read the forum, many information available about how to do that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: Injected 1v, the shorted component pulled just over 2 amps. Felt around the board and found the SMC to be burning hot. Is reflowing worth a shot or should I be replacing the SMC at this point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
Reflow dead SMC???
It is shorted, change it.

First be sure to get 3.42V on L7095; if <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR> is open/corroded, there can be 7V, or more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: SMC changed and board is working! Thanks for the help!
